The engines and its robust construction allow the aircraft to operate from unprepared airstrips, making it a popular choice for remote and inaccessible locations where traditional runways may be limited or absent. It soon became the airplane of choice for humanitarian missions, surveillance, aerial survey, and commercial island hops. entry.title: SIMMAN Releases Khon Kaen International Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. SIMMAN has recently released their rendition of Khon Kaen International Airport (VTUK) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, serving the city of Mueang Khon Kaen in Thailand with a yearly average of 1,568,000 passengers. Built by the Japanese Army during World War 2, the then airfield featured a 1,300-meter-long runway with no navigational aids, which was eventually expanded when the war ended, and the airport was converted into a civilian facility.Â In 1962, the Civil Aviation Authority of Thailand revamped the airport's infrastructure for the first time, building parking lots, hangars, garages, and basic buildings to handle passenger traffic. A year later, Thai Airways started flying to Khon Kaen with a DC-3 from Bangkok to Ubon Ratchathani, carrying passengers, cargo, and mail.Â A new passenger terminal was approved in 2017, expanding the airport's size to 45,500 square meters. The construction work started a year later. The finished project should raise the passenger handling capabilities to 5.5 million passengers a year and support wide-body aircraft like the Airbus A330 and the Boeing 777.Â The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with a 3D terminal and its interior, an up-to-date ground layout, custom ground textures, custom jetways, and custom night lighting. It's available onÂ SimMarketÂ for roughly $18.07, requiring at least 344.83 MB of free hard disk space to install. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: TaiModels Releases Newport News/Williamsburg International Airport for X-Plane 11 & 12
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. TaiModels has recently released their rendition of Newport News/Williamsburg International Airport (KPHF) for X-Plane 11 and 12, serving the Virginia Peninsula in the United States with a yearly average of 430,000 passengers. The airport was originally part of a military base from World War 2, Camp Patrick Henry. They got 924 areas of that land, where they built a 1,100-meter-long runway. Scheduled service started shortly after in November 1949 with Piedmont Airlines and Capital Airlines.Â In 1951, the terminal was heavily damaged by a fire, prompting them to rebuild it and upgrade the airport while at it with an upgraded traffic control tower and a longer runway (400 meters longer). The new passenger terminal was inaugurated in 1955. Williamsburg Airport, then Patrick Henry Airport, was granted international status in 1975, with four airlines serving the airport nonstop: Allegheny, National, Piedmont, and United. The airport could finally handle international traffic (airline and corporate) with a brand-new customs facility. With the airline deregulation in 1978, the airport lost most of its jet service: National in 1978, Piedmont and Allegheny in 1979, and United in 1981.Â In 1984, with the airport falling deeper and deeper into a massive crisis, they hired a new executive director, who brought a new plan to the table: implementing a business park within the airport to attract air carriers. A year later, it was Americaâs fastest-growing airport, the success of which was also repeated in 1986. The jets were back. In September 1990, the airport got its current name: Newport News/Williamsburg International Airport.Â In the early 2000s, they launched another expansion effort, adding new parking lots, opening new passenger concourses, and bringing more airlines.Â For the past decade, the airport has entered a fast decline. It all started with AirTran Airways stopping their operations after its merger with Southwest Airlines, hitting the passenger count significantly. Then, in 2020, Delta suspended their service to Atlanta. In July 2022, there was a glimmer of hope with Avelo Airlines, but they suspended their operations a year later. The airport is only served by American Eagle (Charlotte) and Netjets (Birmingham, Columbus, Knoxville, Minneapolis, Raleigh-Durham, and Teterboro). The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with high-detail models, SAM jetways, high-quality PBR textures, performance-friendly optimization, custom autogen around the airport, ground traffic plugins, and weather textures (X-Plane 12 only). Itâs available onÂ SimMarketÂ for roughly $19.91, requiring at least 1.22 GB of free hard disk space to install. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: FSDesigns Releases Jacksonville International Airport for X-Plane 11 & 12
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. FSDesigns has recently released their rendition of Jacksonville International Airport (KJAX) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, serving the Jacksonville Metropolitan Area with a yearly average of 6,500,000 passengers. Jacksonville International was conceived as a replacement for Imeson Field, which has served Jacksonville since 1927. It was simply not big enough to handle the increased demand for air travel, and the runways could not be expanded due to terrain limitations.Â Inaugurated in 1968, its growth could have been faster, with only two million passengers a year by 1982 (way below expectation). However, the 90s saw a massive increase, with the average hitting the 5 million mark. In 2000, they approved an expansion plan to rebuild the landside terminal, central square, main concessions area, and a parking area expansion. In 2006, they rolled out the second phase of the expansion program, rebuilding concourses A and C, designed by Reynolds, Smith & Hills. The crisis of 2009 stopped any other ongoing expansion work, with the old Concourse B being demolished and only considered for rebuilding ten years later when the traffic figures were healthy again. The pandemic, though, halted that project, which should begin by the summer of 2023. Itâs served by Allegiant Air, American Airlines, American Eagle, Breeze Airways, Delta Air Lines, Delta Connection, Frontier Airlines, JetBlue, Silver Airways, Southwest Airlines, Sun Country Airlines, United Airlines, and United Express. American, Delta, and Southwest hold most of the market share, with 20% each. The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with high-quality 3D models, custom ground textures, an optimized terminal interior, an up-to-date airport layout, SAM jetways, 3D vegetation, dynamic night lighting, and custom wear and tear using the latest technology. Itâs available onÂ the X-Plane.Org StoreÂ for $19.99, requiring at least 1.26 GB of free hard disk space. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

entry.title: FeelThere Releases St. Louis International Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. FeelThere has recently released their rendition of St. Louis Lambert International Airport (KSTL) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, serving metropolitan St. Louis with a yearly average of 13 million passengers. Opened 100 years ago, St. Louis started its life as an airfield with the addition of hangars and a passenger terminal two years later, in 1925. In that same decade, it became one of the first airports to have an air traffic control system, although via flags instead of radio communication. In 1928, it became one of the first municipally owned airports in the United States after the city paid 2 million dollars to Albert Bond Lambert, its owners, and one of the most famous precursors of aviation in St. Louis, being the first licensed pilot in the city and part of the leadership of the Missouri Aeronautical Society. During World War 2, it became a manufacturing facility for McDonnell Aircraft Corporation and Curtiss-Wright. In the 1950s, the airport got a new passenger terminal to handle the increased air travel demand, costing 7.2 million dollars and bringing an innovative dome design that preceded JFK (New York) and CDG (Paris). By 1957, they had 44 weekday TWA departures, 24 from American Airlines, 16 from Delta, 14 from Ozark Airlines, 13 from Eastern Air Lines, six from Braniff, and two from Central.Â In the 1970s, Missouri residents rejected a proposal to build a new airport in suburban Illinois. Later in that decade, the airport underwent a massive expansion project that expanded the runways, increased the number of gates to 81, and boosted its overall capacity.Â Following the airline deregulation in 1978, the dominant forces at St. Louis were TWA with 36 routes and Ozark with 25, followed by American and Eastern with 17 and 12, respectively.Â As a direct consequence of the deregulation, airlines adopted a hub model. St. Louis became one of TWA's hubs, flying people all over America and even across the ocean to London, Paris, and Frankfurt.Â With the aviation crisis that followed 9/11, TWA ceased operations and got bought out by American, which couldn't afford to keep St. Louis as one of their hubs. Southwest preyed on that by boosting their daily departures and overall participation. Currently, they hold 61.40% of the passenger market share, followed by American Airlines (12%) and Delta Air Lines (7.70%).Â The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with over 60 custom buildings, custom animated jetways, custom night lighting, custom ground clutter, realistic terrain elevation, and high-resolution ground textures. It's available onÂ SimMarketÂ for roughly $15.07, requiring at least 685.08 MB of free hard disk space to install. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news! â

The airport was built in 1941 as an Army Air Corps aircraft training and operation base. After the war, it became a large storage, sale, and scrapping center for Army Air Forces aircraft.Â Shortly after, in 1946, the airport was renamed from âOntario Municipal Airportâ to âOntario International Airportâ because of outgoing trans-pacific cargo flights.
